When your way out isn't just an exit

News May 2011

Owners of software companies starta business for many different reasons. At some stage they will be planning for the future exit. Whether the business has been grown specifically for sale or an owner wants to retire or its for other personal reasons, having invested years of hard work, personal sacrifice and endured the stresses and strains of growing the company it is only fair that the Business Owners get a fair and reasonable return for their labours.

Sadly this isnt always the case!

The most common form of owner exit is a trade sale; the sale of the company as a going concern to another business. The buyer of a business is looking for a number of areas of comfort and reassurance from the acquired business

  1. The promise that future revenues and profits will meet or exceed historic performance;
  2. The comfort that the departure of the business owner will not be perceived negatively by its customers;
  3. The promise that their own customers will perceive the acquisition in a positive light; and
  4. The assurance that the business managers, excluding the selling Directors, are more than capable of running the business day to day in the new regime.

Most of these assurances are intangible and based on the acquiring businesss perception of the business for sale. To achieve the best possible valuation, the Selling Directors needs to manage the market perception including their customers, prospective customers and potential acquirers. Without a proactive approach, the result is a weak valuation and a lock in for the sellers who can only achieve their exit valuation on an earn out.

So, how should you go about preparing a company for sale and achieving the best valuation?

One thing that is common to all businesses that grow is that founders have to become more like Directors and Leaders rather than Managers or Supervisors. (See our white paper "Are you a leader or a manager. The Small Business Owners Dilemma"). Successfully growing a software company requires a focus on short term tactical issues including month on month sales, customer support and credit control as well as strategic initiatives such as geographic growth, new product development or new service delivery.

One of the most important strategic projects a business can embark on is a trade sale. While the sale itself can be undertaken in weeks, the planning, positioning and preparation for the sale needs much longer. This needs to be undertaken as a Strategic Project with the aim of maximising Shareholder Value. Specifically this will include;

  1. Building a revenue model which provides assurance of future performance;
  2. Building a customer perception of a team being Directed but not supervised;
  3. Building a value proposition that the market will view positively; and
  4. Creating a responsible and accountable management team independent of the owners.

It is most common that a business owner only sells one company in their career. This gives them a solitary pay day for their labours. With the guidance from an Executive Coach who has a been a buyer and a seller of businesses they can maximise their perception in the market; achieve a realistic valuation and ultimately a fair reward for building a business which can truly transcend their efforts.

If you are considering how to exit your business and would like a free no obligation conversation call me on 01536 771440 or visit my website for more information.
